text: International Bestseller, Atomic Habits: an easy & proven way to build good habits & break bad ones by James Clear is filled with the best science on personal growth and success. Also on the cover, it says, “Tiny changes, remarkable results.”Mr. Clear’s premise is that only making a 1 percent improvement each day compounds to make remarkable results over time.In each chapter, Clear cites scientific research that points out these principles and how to break one’s goals down into micro-goals and tasks that are manageable into 2-minute time frames and stacked with one’s current habits in order to cement the new practice with something that’s already done habitually subconsciously.Overall, I found this book very helpful in how to take baby steps to transform my life – in any and all areas of my life. I consider it a ‘keeper,’ that I will refer to over and over as I implement these suggestions.I highly recommend this book for anyone who’s a student of personal growth or business success.
title: filled with the best science on personal growth and success

text: I found the four laws easy to understand and apply. Two things especially useful were the concepts about 'the plateau of latent potential', and 'the three layers of behavior change'. I believe that if we adopt identity-based behavior we can overcome the barriers to reaping the rewards that lie beyond our latent potential.I gladly recommend reading this book.
title: Practical and easy to apply for behavior change

text: This book has a lot of great information but I can't get past the countless spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and run-on sentences. This is the WORST edit of a book I have ever read, and it's sold over a million copies!? Can they not fix all these errors and re-print?Terrible.
title: Way too many spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, run-on sentences...

text: First of all: don't buy this version of the book. Incredible poor quality, torn pages, poor formatting, suddenly different fonts appear, etc.Content-wise: I kept reading many recommendations about this book and eventually bought it. Therefore, I probably held high expecations of it which were increased when James Clear claims that he would extend findings of luminaries such as B.F. Skinner. Long story short: he does not.From start to end the book remains very superficial. I am sure there are many good take aways for readers who have no prior (or scientific) knowledge about this topic. Others I recommend to watch a Youtube-Video of the author. That's all you need - the rest of the book are just stories.A better book for this type of content is "Switch" by the Heath brothers.Readers of this book should also be very cautious from a psychological perspective. Creating habits can be very helpful but if you overdue it (like it is frequently suggested in this book) you might be prone to a life characterized by compulsiveness and unease.
title: Disappointed

text: This book clearly and concisely lays out how to build and sustain habits in your life. I would recommend it to anyone who wants to change their routines.I have enjoy James' website for years. The writing style is clear and direct. The book is broken into bite sized chapters which distill the core ideas from the book. I know I am going to be using the chapter summaries for years to come whenever I need a refresher.The book is quite dense. I intentionally tried to read it more slowly to let the ideas sink in. There are a few exercises throughout the book which you should definitely do to reinforce the material.I have read many other habits books and would recommend this one too.
title: The manual to building better habits

text: Atomic Habits ist das Buch, auf das ich gewartet habe, ohne davon zu wissen. In einer leicht zugänglichen Sprache wird strukturiert und aufeinander aufbauend erklärt, wie Gewohnheiten unser Leben bestimmen und wie wir sie ganz einfach für uns nutzen können.Ich kann das Buch allen empfehlen, die mit kleineren oder grösseren Dingen ihres alltäglichen Lebens nicht zufrieden sind, die schlechte Gewohnheiten los werden oder gute Gewohnheiten fördern wollen. Die Methode ist einfach anwendbar und erfolgversprechend.Meine Erwartungen waren eigentlich recht gering und auf den ersten Seiten kam mir alles etwas zu amerikanisch vor, amerikanisch im Sinn von: Auch Du kannst super erfolgreich werden und den amerikanischen Traum wahr werden lassen, aber das Buch hat mich echt überzeugt.Wer das Buch nicht lesen will und doch neugierig ist, das Hörbuch tut's auch. Allerdings hat die Druckversion hilfreiche Tabellen und einfache Grafiken drin, die das Gesagte vor Augen führen und späteres Nachschlagen einfach machen.
title: Einleuchtend, praktikabel, genial!

text: Ehrlich gesagt verstehe ich nicht, warum dieses Buch derzeit so gehypt wird. Mal wieder hat jemand versucht, dem Leben einen tieferen Sinn zu verleihen, indem er ein paar simple Allgemeinplätze widerkäut. Jedem, der eine einigermaßen "normale" Erziehung genossen hat, dürfte wohl klar sein, dass Gewohnheiten einen Einfluss aufs Leben haben. Und dass Gewohnheiten zu Gewohnheiten werden, wenn man sie stetig widerholt, ist ja wohl auch nichts Neues. Als "life-changing" würde ich das Buch jedenfalls nicht bezeichnen. Allenfalls als kleinen Motivator, mal in die Gänge zu kommen.
title: Als Motivator ganz nett - als "Lifechanger" leider ein Totalversager! :-)

text: I am a business owner from Berlin, Germany. I profited a lot from this book. In this short review, I'd like to highlight just three concepts from the book.First, the author says that habits are the compound interest of self improvement. Many people give up a long time before they can experience the compound effect of their efforts. So when going after a worthwile goal, then what is needed is a lot of patience and perseverence.Second, the author says it's good to have goals but it's so much better to have a system and concentrate on executing the system instead. Because if we do just that, we can be happy every time we execute our plan.Third, identity change is the fastest way to get what we want in life.Instead of saying: "I want to work out three times a week" we could be saying: "I am an athletic person" or instead of saying "I want to write a book" we should be saying to ourselves: "I am an author" - because what does an author do? He writes. It's really as easy as that.
title: These three concepts have helped me achieve my goals a lot faster

text: Are you self-motivated but have trouble finishing what you start? So did I, until I read Atomic Habits. The surprisingly simple techniques this book will teach you will make you feel like you can do anything. I was procrastinating about everything, now everything I want in life is cultivating one habit at a time. I made my whole family read this book after I was done with it. It is seriously a game changer. I recommend it to anyone who has dreams or goals but not the consistency and drive to achieve them.
title: Turned my Life Around

text: Das Buch beginnt mit einer kurzen Einführung, und einer Schilderung welche die Beweggründe des Autors näher beleuchtet. Danach kommt er zügig zum Punkt und man wird mit hilfreichen Modellen und Methoden vertraut gemacht, die einem dabei helfen sollen nützliche Gewohnheiten zu etablieren und schlechte Angewohnheiten auszumustern.Das Ganze wird mit Fallbeispielen und Anekdoten ausgeschmückt, und dazwischen gibts jede Menge übersichtliche Tabellen, Zusammenfassungen und konkrete Handlungsanweisungen. Ich persönlich fand die Balance dabei angemessen.Die vorgestellten Konzepte klingen vielversprechend, und laden zum ausprobieren ein. Vor allem die kleinen Kniffe um ins Tun zu kommen sind meines Erachtens besonders hilfreich, und erhöhen die Chance durchzuhalten bis ein angestrebtes Verhalten sich als Teil der Persönlichkeit manifestiert hat.Perfektion ist dabei nicht notwendig. Vielmehr zeigt sich, dass ein durchdachtes System von Gewohnheiten an sich ein mächtiges Werkzeug ist, mit dem Vieles möglich wird, sofern man dranbleibt. Schließlich bringen einen auch kleine Schritte dem Ziel näher.Um bei der Verfolgung von Vorsätzen und guten Absichten nicht die Orientierung bzw. die Motivation zu verlieren, können die Ideen aus diesem Buch sicher einen wertvollen Beitrag leisten. Gerade in den Momenten, wo es wirklich darauf ankommt, kann das den Unterschied ausmachen.
title: Dranbleiben

text: Ein must read. Das Buch ist sehr gut und auch wenn ich den Inhalt schon kannte, da ich seit Jahren ein E-Mail Abo von James Clear über seine Ideen/Ansichten habe, ist es empfehlenswert es zu kaufen. Der Autor ist kein Übertreiber, auch wenn man es von einem amerikanischen Autor in diesem Bereich fast erwartet. Seine Darstellungen sind moderat in der Sprache, zurückhaltend, aber auch auf einer tiefgründigen Art und Weise  überzeugend. Er begründet seine Thesen mit eigener oder fremder Erfahrung, oft auch mit wissenschaftlichen Studien. Die Ideen sind leicht in den Alltag zu integrieren-das ist eigentlich auch der Sinn des Buches.Mich hat das Buch sehr inspiriert, auch wenn ich bestimmte Teile davon schon als Artikel gelesen habe. Die Aufmachung, Design, Papier, Schrift, Sprache und Schaubilder-alles ist auf einem hohen Niveau und erhöht den Spaß beim Lesen.
title: Sehr gut

text: This book has really got me thinking and working on improving positive habits in my day to day life. I can see a real practical impact from this book.On the flip side it is riddled with spelling and grammar mistakes.  It is as if it wasn't proof read at all.  Seems silly for a book of this nature.
title: Great content but so many typos!

text: My review is not on the book’s content. It is on the quality of the print and paper printed on. I’ve attached several images that show the faded beige paper, several print smudges and print overlays that made me put-off reading this book. I’ll be returning this book for these reasons.
title: Poor paper and print quality

text: La entrega ha sido rapida y el libro estaba en perfectas condiciones.Este libro lo tengo tanto físico como en ebook y es uno de los libros más practicos escritos hasta la fecha para mejorar y modificar tus hábitos.Muy recomendado
title: Libro práctico

text: This book helps you / me change one's habit and become more "successful" in reaching one's goals. I have already put in practice some of those points (which is not a given for so called "self-help" books).I found this book well structured, written and clear. With summaries all over the book (at the end of each chapter, at the end of the book) one can really retain the essence of it and look it up again quickly.I'd recommend this book to people who are willing to make tiny changes in their lives to improve their "effectiveness".
title: No rocket science, but clear and practical

text: Il libro descrive, a livello teorico e pratico, cosa sono e come funzionano le abitudini. La prima parte è teorica e spiega i principi. La seconda parte è pratica e dice come mettere in pratica buone abitudini e come disinnescare le cattive abitudini, sostituendole con abitudini migliori. Raccomandato.
title: Eccellente

text: I chanced upon James Clears’ blog on a random Google search for my “Next Book to Read”. After checking his list of recommendations, I read a few of his posts and I was hooked. The writing was easy to read and understand, his research thorough and reading his posts felt like having a personal life coach cheering you from afar.When I saw Atomic Habits listed on his website, I was very keen to read it. Fast forward 6 months, I finally purchased the kindle version and I am thrilled with it. The book follows his usual style of writing – which is crisp, easy to read and packs a punch. There are actionable insights in the book, that when implemented consistently, can bring about significant changes in our lives. No task seems too big to achieve – ask anyone who has tried building a new habit or deleting an old one from their lives, how difficult it is to keep at it for 21 days or 60 or 90 (depending on which literature you’re reading). But the methods listed in this book can allow you to overcome failure just as easily as they encourage you to successfully implement new habits.The ideas listed in the book are forgiving and generous, quite literally, where some ask you to focus on incremental gains, some don’t reprimand you for missing one day of a new diet / workout schedule, others give you simple, straightforward suggestions to increase your chances of success in implementing new habits.There’s no long story, scientific jargon, unnecessary fillers or flimsy writing to make you NOT want to turn the page. This is definitely worth your money and time.
title: Atomic Habits: James Clear

text: The book starts with some basic but crucial info about how small amount of effort each day can make a great difference in the long run. Then it gets more deep in the formation of the habit and how the behaviour can change. It states clearly that Identity has a dramatic influence on formation of the habits. As you read more the book it points out to how one can create a good habit or simply destroy the bad one step by step.  There are list of notes, references and citations at the end of book that verifies what author has stated make sense and this is what makes this book precious. It was such an incredible journey for me to read this book since I have just started to form a new habit in my life and this book definitely helped me to stay motivated and simply know myself better. I want to thanks James Clear for writing such a brilliant book.
title: Scientific and sociological approach of the author to why and how habits exist and can be created

text: Message great but very difficult to concentrate due to the incredible volume of typos.  There are so many elementary typos and grammatical errors that it's difficult to believe anyone actually proof read it.  I could easily add many more example pics, but I'd be here all day uploading them - there are so many!
title: Shocking Grammar - Incredibly number of typos.

text: Overall not a bad book. The premise to this book is good. I started off strong with this book as there were great concepts and examples, but I found it difficult to continue reading as I felt like a lot of the “habits” and theories were a bit repetitive. Great concepts but I found I got more value from re-reading “ 7 habits of highly effective people.” I found that this read too much like a textbook and as it continue lost its appeal.
title: Not a bad book, but found it to be a bit repetitive.

text: While the content of the book in the first 50 pages is fantastic I've discovered that the book is missing pages, and some pages are not in order.  Will reorder from another seller as the content is thought provoking.
title: Pages missing/out of sequence

text: This is as amazing book! It provides you with tools to change your habits and become the person you want to be. If you change little by little, habit by habit, 1% by 1% improvements (hence the name "Atomic Habits"), you might not see a huge difference in the beggining, but those improvements compound on one another and when you look at yourself, you already accomplished amazing things.
title: Incredibly practical and realistic book. It provides the tools you need to change your life

text: I contenuti del libro sono chiari, utili e immediatamente applicabili. Le tecniche discusse possono sembrare "banali" a posteriori, ma in realtà la maggior parte di esse sono cose a cui normalmente non si pensa. Ho scelto la versione in inglese per tenermi allenato con la lingua e devo dire che, tranne qualche eccezione, il vocabolario utilizzato è di facile comprensione per qualunque persona che abbia una discreta conoscenza dell'inglese. Molto carini e utili anche i vari grafici e le tabelle riepilogative.
title: Libro utilissimo

text: I have read a lot of self development books and the one on willpower was great but this one is just amazing. The writer put in awesome information from all over the topic - habits and gives us a bunch of unbelievable useful tools to put into practise in our lives. I love the writing style. It is very entertaining because he also uses a lot of stories to support each one of his points. I am just half way through the book but it already blew my pretty stoneage mind :) lol
title: Genius book!

text: Es un excelente libro para cualquier persona. A mí personalmente cómo Nutriólogo me ha ayudado a facilitar el proceso de cambio de hábitos en mis pacientes. He empezado a aplicar los principios del libro y veo mejores resultados.
title: Excelente libro

text: Do you want to work out more often, or finally improve your Spanish vocabulary? This book is so helpful in building good habits and reducing bad ones. It explains how you should build your identity on your new habit (not: “I am dabbling in yoga”, but “I’m a yogi and it makes me feel great”), to make your progress visible (e.g. using beans or paper clips which you move from one jar to another), to reward yourself, get a buddy and hold yourself accountable, not breaking the habit..., etc. Highly recommended.
title: Very useful, highly practical

text: The book content is mostly about things that you feel that you already knew; but everything is presented in a logical and practical way using carefully chosen words. Overall, the book helped me to understand better what I have been doing and how to find ways to improve in some ways, and not unimprove in others.Overall, the book has a clear language and structure, and has many references and practical examples making the read easy and fast. I personally like this a lot, since I've read some chapters again for better understanding.
title: A very interesting read

text: El autor utiliza su experiencia como un claro ejemplo de lo que un hábito puede ayudarte a lograr. Imaginarias que el describir como cambiar hábitos o adoptar nuevos, terminaría siendo como un libro de autoayuda o motivacional que la mayor parte del tiempo hasta ahí llega, pero James a hecho un excelente trabajo simplificando los factores que motivan y desinhiben hábitos y lo mejor de todo ejemplificandolos de manera muy clara.
title: Un excelente trabajo en base a experiencia

text: Excellent read, common sense laid out attractively well. Practical points supported by real life stories. This book is a gem. Guaranteed, you won’t be the same person if you read it carefully.
title: James nailed it

text: I'm still reading this book but so far it's been amazing. I was feeling stuck in rut and this book is definitely making me think differently. I don't want to spoil the book but this is a must read, if you're feeling like you're not where you want to be, you're not meeting your weight loss goals or and goals in general, maybe if you're just looking to optimise your life.
title: Must Read Book

text: Ich fande das Buch sehr informativ und interessant. Man konnte einiges Mitnehmen.Nach dem Buch war man reflektierter und konnte auch im Alltag bestimmte Situationen wiedererkennen, die James Clear in seinem Buch beschrieb.Leider bin ich nie 100% in einen Lesefluss hineingekommen, was ich etwas schade fande.Trotzdem ein gutes Buch, was man gelesen haben sollte.
title: + Informativ - Kam leider kein Lesefluss zustande

text: Gran libro pieno di tanti consigli utili per costruire e mantenere buone abitudini ed eliminare quelle cattive. Utilissimo anche per raggiungere i nostri obiettivi, dato che anche quelli possono richiedere tante piccole azioni quotidiane. Consigliato
title: Libro da non perdere

text: Owned this for some time, finally read it. The habit loop is literally now on my fridge, and everyone at home is constantly aware of where they are in the habit loop when it comes to making a decision.Wish I had decided to read this earlier.Only downside is that there are not too many strategies past one or two examples (per subsection), especially for “breaking bad habits”.
title: Immersive, comprehensive - Wish I had read it earlier

text: The author rightly asserts that motivation is not about infinite willpower but deploying limited willpower.  It’s about focusing willpower in a streamlined way to get concrete results.  The book details the steps and tricks to accomplish favourable outcomes.
title: Cure for lack of motivation and output

text: Either good or bad, James Clear presents the four major pillars of why we stick to the habits we hold on a daily basis. Whether you are looking for new year's resolutions to become a reality, or simply know about human behavior, this is a must (and easy) read.
title: An excellent compilation of why we stick to habits.

text: This book brings together many aspects of other habit books and literature. Great stories to introduce each concept. Plus lots of actionable advice. This will be in the referral rotation for habits for sure.
title: Awesome book for the art and science of habits

text: Much like the methods described in the book, every sentence of this book adds wisdom. Which is the best? Like the Sorites paradox (how does a single coin make you rich?), which sentence will do the trick?It's a wonderful accessible read. Highly recommended.
title: Impossible to Summarise

text: I bought Atomic Habits just out of curiosity after reading 'The Power of Habits' and was not expecting much. To my surprise, this book takes the psychology of habits to the next level and has the power to bring real positive change in your life. I have been able to start a morning routine, stick to existing good habits and break the bad ones (some of them) from the learnings of this book.I also subscribe to James Clear's newsletter which acts as a weekly refresher to some of the concepts from this book and keeps you motivated to continue building good habits.
title: Life changing !

text: Great Insights which will really make your life better. Must read for everyone.I have been following James for 4 years now he's always produced quality work.
title: Great INSIGHTS.YOU Would be GLAD.

text: This is an excellent book for anyone trying to change an aspect of their life. It's inspirational and practical at the same time.I had already listened to this book twice on Audible when I decided I needed to have a physical copy as well. I wanted to be able to highlight key parts of the book to keep for reference later.
title: Best book I have read in a long time!

text: Buena lectura que demuestra que para ser bueno en algo tiene que hacerse con un hábito. Una estrella menos porque creo que se extiende más de la cuenta.
title: Muy buena lectura.

text: Everything the author mentions about this book may sound obvious, but when you start practicing it and making small changes in your life you can achieve many things. I started by being a little bit more organized, then I built a  excercise routine then I started using more my agenda and so on. I don't know where this is going to take me, but I've been feeling better since I started building atomic habits.
title: Amazingly good!

text: Bei diesem Buch merkt man, wie sehr sich der Autor James Clear mit der Materie auseinandergesetzt hat, über die er dieses Buch geschrieben hat. Und er schafft es, komplexe psychologische bzw. kognitive Vorgänge, die bei der Entstehung und Aufrechterhaltung von Habits (also Routinen und Gewohnheiten) eine Rolle spielen, auf eine verständliche Ebene herunterzubrechen und in eine gut zu verfolgende Schritt-für-Schritt-Anleitung zu übersetzen. Well done!
title: Geniales Buch

text: This is a review of the seller not the content of the book.  This book is poorly printed and looks to have been photocopied from the original version.  Do not buy from this seller, the book is counterfeit.
title: Photocopied book by OPUSKART AU

text: From the beginning to the end this book is filled with very clear and practical mechanisms to realize your bad habits and eliminate them gradually and to build the habits and systems that support you with achieving your goals in any aspects of your life.I have already implemented two effective habits putting my Facebook app on block site for certain hours during the day so I don't waste time there unconc
title: This boo offers Practical and Clear Mechanisms to build systems that can help you achieve your desir

text: James Clear, clearly lists out several ways to improve ourselves with ease everyday by only doing 1%. I implore you read this and not find something that will benefit you. Good luck with that!
title: Fantastic book

text: I really enjoyed this book: the content and the way it is written. I've given it as a gift. If you take the ideas presented and apply them conscientiously, this book could prove pivotal in improving your life. Excellent work, James Clear!
title: Sensible, useable premise and tips!

text: Das Buch beschreibt die Psychologie der Gewohnheiten und wie man solche bauen kann. Der Autor postuliert 4 Gesetze und beschreibt ein System,  um gute oder schlechte Gewohnheiten auf- oder abzubauen.Das Buch ist leicht zu lesen, in angenehmen Stil geschrieben, mit ganz vielen Verweisen auf diverse Quellen und Studien.Es gibt nur eine Sache, die mich total nervt - es gibt auch Verweise auf die Webseite des Buchs, die nicht mehr existiert. Damit man die Materialien herunterladen kann, die ursprünglich auf dieser Seite zu finden waren, muss man jetzt den Kaufbeleg an eine bestimmte Email-Addresse schicken.Und wie das so mit Selbsthilfe Bücher ist - man kann sie gerne lesen, aber man muss auch anwenden, was man gelesen hat. Ein Zitat aus dem Buch:"Until you work as hard as those you admire, don't explain away their success as luck."
title: Gutes Buch - empfehlenswert

text: A great book indeed. I read the entire thing in one sitting. The ideas are simple yet powerful and definitely work to improve your productivity, achievement and understanding of yourself and your habits. This book is like a guide on how to win against yourself.Sidenote: I am a professional dog trainer, and the techniques to motivate and achieve behaviours in dogs are remarkably similar to the techniques to motivate and change behaviours in humans as outlined in this book!
title: One of those books that changes your outlook on life

text: This book is one of the top ten books that have changed my life.So many of the results we get in life depend on our habits.This book explains the exact mechanisms you can use to create new, positive habits, and to let go of old, unhelpful habits.The author uses simple habits as examples but once you understand the principles, you can apply them to any habit in any area of your life.
title: Outstanding book

text: Mit großen Gewinn habe ich dieses Buch verschlungen. Auch für nicht Muttersprachler gut verständlich geschrieben. Übersichtlich. Nicht zu viele Geschichten. Viele Fakten. Praxisorientierte Anleitungen und Beispiele. Sehr herausfordernd und doch sofort umsetzbar. Dankeschön!
title: Kompakt, praxisorientiert, herausfordernd

text: This was a Great Read.The books has a number of practical tips that we can implement in our daily life to be more productive. I felt like the author has known the depth of human feelings when it comes to anxiety and stress regarding their lifestyle.I would surely really recommend this to any one.
title: Great Book

text: Haven’t read it finished yet but it’s a meaningful and beneficial read, gives an insight on how you can eliminate or reduce the things you don’t wanna do but have always been.
title: A good way to develop yourself

text: I thought this will be another version of the famous book the ‘The power of habit” but it is not.This book is different. Provides a practical manual of how to develop good habits and get rid of bad ones. Highly recommended.
title: Different to The Power of Habit

text: If your struggling to achieve overwhelming objectives this is the book that will help you get there without beating yourself up at every perceived failure!  Interesting and easy to apply.  Advice that resonates!
title: Resonating

text: Excellent book. One of the best for anyone looking for self improvement with some high quality writing and stories to keep it interesting.Paperback book quality was very good as expected.Thanks.
title: Great book. Must read/buy.

text: This book is well written and well set out with a balance of studies plus personal insights by the author but stays on track. I have found it thought provoking and expanding my view of my daily routine and attitude. It has depth, not just one idea repeated lots of different ways. Generally I am a speed reader, but have gone against type for this book, by taking my time and rereading many sections. I am onto my third read thru the entire book as I work my way thru the sections, that can be applied to your everyday behaviours. I can highly recommend.
title: Gives you food for thought

text: the chapter titles have a lot of dots around itbut it's just a minor nitpick it's actually fine thankfully not as bad as what others have stated in their reviews.book wise, i already read it and it's a really good book. I ordered one more as a gift for a friend
title: book is great, printing quality... ehhhhhhhhhhh.

text: Can’t recommend this enough. Definitely the most enjoyable book I’ve read about self-development!Every chapter starts with a real story of how others have made or broken habits to enhance their performance. The examples used are really interesting and always relevant to habits, and are used to explain the less interesting stuff so it never gets boring! Well done to James Clear. Not a single bad thing to say, this book is worth the money.
title: THE ONLY BOOK YOU’LL EVER NEED TO MAKE OR BREAK HABITS

text: Fantastic book! If you read this book you can change your life and become who you want to be. Lose weight, write a book, save to for retirement, etc... I'm a huge believer that this book can help you change and become the person you want to be.
title: Become Who You Want To Be!

text: One of the best books I’ve readReally helped with my focus and organizationLess is more in life and this book helped with thatHighly recommend!
title: Excellent book. Must read!

text: I love it so much I’m already re-reading it.  This is one of those game changer books that make you actually go out and take action and become a better version of yourself.
title: Amazing book that will change your life.

text: + a practical approach for setting up Habits+ Worth reading with many practical examples- 30% of the book contains references,  notes and irrelevant info. :(
title: A Good Read !

text: Wohl eins der besten Bücher die ich gelesen habe. Jeder der Probleme hat sich Gewohnheiten anzutrainieren ist mit diesem Buch bestens gewappnet. Natürlich ist es kein Zauber Buch und man ist selbst mit gefragt, aber es gibt euch alle Werkzeuge die ihr benötigt
title: Super

text: Do not buy this paperback version. It has the worst printing quality. Ink marks everywhere, some pages got too much ink, some got too little ink. And, in the back of the book, it even says:"for sale in the Indian subcontinent only". That may explain why this book is so poor printed.
title: Bad printing

text: A very easy to follow guide in how to make your life more successful and enjoyable. He proposes a simple yet powerful system which can be applied right away. Good stuff, highly recommended
title: Very clear and true.

text: I've been reading James Clear's articles for some time and I have watched him grow from an article writer to a Best selling author. I would recommend this book again and again. My performance level has increased just by reading this book and the articles he has been writing for years. I'm very grateful James. God bless you
title: The Best book I have read

text: Es un libro bastante digerible, didáctico y con muchos ejemplos de la vida real.Habla sobre 4 puntos para cambiar hábitos malos, generar buenos hábitos y mantenerlos.
title: Excelente libro para cambiar estilos de vida

text: This book deserve 5 stars because it gives great advices on how to change habits. The chapters are shorts and all very interesting. I would read every morning 2 chapters before starting my day and apply my learnings through out the day. I recommand this book to everybody.  I wish I had read this book earlier in my life!
title: Excellent book!

text: arrivato con angolo copertina piegato, però pazienza , in pacchi del genere non posso aspettarmi altro.Libro interessante e da leggere almeno una volta nella vita
title: bellissimo libro

text: Un libro súper fácil de leer con muchísimos consejos de cómo construir hábitos y la importancia de esto. Consejos aplicables fácilmente. Acabas el libro queriendo ser tu mejor versión.
title: Muy práctico y entretenido

text: James has perfectly captured the mechanics of habits and behavior. He has compiled a lot of information from different sources and studies and presented it in a clear, concise manner.Anybody who wants to make make a meaningful change but is struggling with keeping up, grab a copy. This is all you need.
title: Really enjoyed reading this book

text: Wenn man sich damit auseinandersetzten will, schlechte Gewohnheiten abzulegen und auch einfach mal die täglichen Gewohnheiten zu hinterfragen, dann ist das genau das richtige Buch dafür.Es ist sehr verständlich geschrieben und das ein oder andere Aha-Erlebnis war beim Lesen schon mal dabei.Meiner Meinung nach ein "Handbuch" um neue Routinen und Gewohnheiten zu etablieren - mit diesem Buch hat man den theoretischen Teil in seinen Händen, jetzt geht's nur mehr ans umsetzen!
title: Tolles Buch!

text: I've read many books on the topic. Bravo James, it is so clear and useful, this book is must! One of the most practical and best I've read year and I've a lot in 2021.Thank you so much!
title: Clear plan to master yourself

text: Complex topics explained simply and succinctly. Entertaining, actionable and insightful. Habits are systems not goals.....GOLD, thank you James!It was like reading a book by an old friend. I look forward to James's emails every week and this book takes his learnings to the next level.
title: my favourite emails are now my new favourite book

text: I have always wonder how to keep up with my new habits, after reading the book I just got it. It's a matter of balancing. It's looking what we do in a different way
title: Habita seen in a diferent way

text: Great brook to understand habits in a very deep and practical level, i enjoyed this book a lot, i would recommend it to anyone interested in understanding their day to day behaviour.
title: Amazing

text: I like the real life examples.Hearing about the pros getting bored and getting it done anyway was good to know.Every little bit counts weather it's good or bad.I
title: Good read about how and why habits work and don't

text: Must read , read it on audible and then bought a hard copy to be able to go back and re read certain parts . Loved it , very helpful and the way its written is very enjoyable
title: Get it you won't regret it

text: Atomic Habits describes a system of creating or eliminating habits, and explains why self-control and willpower are insufficient for lasting change. I especially liked the discussions of identity.
title: Habits systematized

text: The book is full of useful advice about developing new habits. The only problem I have with it is that the author quotes quite a lot of other books about habits, which makes me wonder how much of the book is actually original.
title: Useful advice

text: Tenia muchisimas ganas de leer este libro pero me ha llegado mal. Hay sobrante de hoja que no se ha cortado como se puede apreciar en la foto.
title: Me ha llegado en mal estado

text: Bel libro consiglio vivamente piccole cose che se applicate nella vita quotidiana migliorAno decisamente la vita e aiuta raggiungere propri obbiettivi.
title: Consigliatissimo

text: This book is a great guide to help you become aware of how to change your behaviour patterns and thus, change your life outcomes. I recommend it for anybody, but especially for young people. Although children, teenagers and university students will find this book extremely helpful, it’s also good for adults, who may be looking to get unstuck in their ways.
title: An effective guide to change your habits

text: Enseña claramemte las mejores tecnicas para lograr todo lo que  tu deseas y hace constar que nada grande se logra sin buenos habitos
title: Gran libro

text: With simplicity and clarity, James writes about habits and how they shape our lives.If you want to accomplish 2019 wishes, I highly recommend this book.
title: The best book I've read in 2018

text: I can't stop recommending this book to my family and friends. It's so funny how we think on a daily basis about processes to constantly improve our routines and collaborations at work, but hadn't yet really thought systematically about it for my personal life. In fact, the word "habit" was not much in my daily vocabulary. Thinking of how to create good new habits and break bad ones through small "optimization processes" is perfect!
title: Good job James!

text: As someone who, prior to reading this book, identified as a workaholic - this book has shifted my entire perspective about personal identity and how our habits should reflect who we aspire to be. I am so grateful that I chose to read this book.
title: Powerful New Perspectives

text: I saw lots of ways I can improve my daily life just by following the simple advice given in this book. Already started doing some and finding myself almost effortlessly being more productive.
title: Excellent

text: I read this and it helped a lot with helping me understand my eating habits. It also helped me guide some of my employees with their work at home routines. There are great discussions to be had. I recommend reading this as a book club with employees or colleagues.
title: Great read

text: Everything was perfect but the seller send it with the name "DHL" instead of my own name! I faced a lot of hassle for that. However, the book quality is great.
title: Book was perfect but delivery was not

text: Me está resultando realmente útil su lectura. Me parece un libro muy bueno que he recomendado encarecidamente a mis próximos. Fácil de aplicar, me está ayudando a simplificar y conseguir objetivos.
title: CLARO - DIRECTO - ÚTIL

text: Es sind in der Tat die Kleinigkeiten, die einen in der Spur halten um ans Ziel zu kommen. Ich habe während des Lesens von diesem Buch1. aufgehört zu rauchen2. angefangen andere Bücher zu lesen3. das Journal schreiben entdeckt4. den nächsten Tag am Abend vorher vorzubereitenDie Ergebnisse in den zwei Wochen sind absolut toll, ich bin auf das Langzeitergebnis gespannt.
title: Absolut Empfehlenswert

text: So many works about habits are more along the lines or same old same old. Clear brings excellent research but more so really practical ways to change, something we all need! Well done.
title: Practical

text: I cannot wait to read the book; this review relates to the product itself. The book quality for price is terrible. The printing is haphazard, with some words difficult to read as they didn't fully print properly - the top half of some words are completely missing. The front cover had dirty marks all over it which gives the impression it wasn't brand new. The quality of the paper felt very cheap. The price is high for such low quality.
title: High Price for Low Quality

text: Fantastic and easy read with strategies to incorporate right away. Has definitely impacted how I look at things and how I need to tweak my current habits system. A lifelong resource. Hightly recommend.
title: Awesome book

text: I doubt even the most barely functioning of adults will find anything in this book new or insightful. The book contains little more than a few obvious observations and ridiculous anecdotes, such as hairdressers being able to tell if someone is pregnant by the feel of thier hair (due to the power of habit).
title: Incredibly basic

text: To passionate self improvement geeks, many of the ideas in this book will sound Familiar. Nevertheless, it is the great structuring work of the author and adding examples where the book delivers great additional value. This is a very comprehensive Guide into the science of habits.
title: Very structured guide towards great habits

text: To change an habit or understand how we make ours, w great read and immediately actionable in our daily lives
title: Great book

text: Es ist wirklich eine tolle Grundlage der Persönlichkeitsenwicklung. Es kann einem wirklich helfen, wenn man die genannten Tipps und Informationen ernst nimmt. an sich gut und einfach verständlich geschrieben.
title: Gute Denkanstöße

text: This book is the absolute best I read on habit building. Took so many notes. Tons of usable info! Very well written. James went all out.
title: Definitely a must read.

text: this book provides the reader with tools, clear reasoning and a potential plan to address deliberate habitual creation and deliberate habitual removal / replacement for bad habits. Great read. Profound and practical!
date: Reviewed in the Netherlands on 19 March 2019
title: Great read. Profound and practical!

text: Great book if you want to get your life in focus and get rid of unwanted habits. Whether you want to stop procrastination or build a new habit, this is the book for you. It's very easy to read and flows very nicely, definitely a great purchase for any book collection.

text: Excellent writing, lots of stories and examples - a very easy read. Actionable ideas that anyone can start applying immediately.

text: Libro spettacolare, scorrevolissimo ed estremamente chiaro. Mi ha dato tantissimi spunti per riuscire a incorporare nuove abitudini alla mia routine e disfarmi di altre che ritengo deleterie. Veramente un must have per tutti gli appassionati di questo genere di letteratura!
title: Libro meraviglioso!!! Must have per gli amanti della letteratura sulla crescita personale!

title: Finally I understand why bad habits are hard to break

text: I learn many technics I will definitely use!I highly recommend to anyone who is looking to add good habits to their lives or get rid of bad ones.

title: Naja

title: Better than Charles Duhigg

text: Maybe not unique in its kind, but the framework makes it really easy to apply & retain.100% advised. Can be broadly applied.

title: Great book with a fantastic underlying framework for maximal benefits.

text: Tolles Buch. Ich liebe die kleinen Kapitel, so dass sich das Buch super in der Bahn lesen lässt. An einigen Stellen wird etwas sehr religiös gehandelt, aber ansonsten einfach toll.

text: Excellent book for those wanting to start and maintain good habits. Clear provides interesting perspectives and references experiments that reinforce his tips for building habits.
title: Great for Habit Building

text: If you were only to read on book in your entire life, it would be this. If you're just starting to pick up reading and need a first book to break the ice, it would be this. Honestly Atomic Habits is like the foundational book you build upon.Physical book-wise its standard sized with really good quality paper.
title: THE book you should read

text: Atomic habits is a book that breaks down habits into systems. It guides you from understanding what a habit is, why we continue our habits and shows a strategy to build better habits. I think anyone who reads this book will get great take homes from it!
title: Fantastic Lessons

text: This book is very life changing and a must read for people who want to get successful in nearly any field. Ive given it only four instead of five stars because it gets a bit repetitive in my opinion.
title: Life-changing!

text: Most self help books give you sensation of "wow that was a great read" but then leave you with no direct actionable steps to implement what they have taught. This book is the complete opposite. It is a complete breakdown of what to do and how. The only way it could be any better is if James would upload a youtube series of him actually breaking down his habits in real time.
title: Ironic that his last name is clear, because his information is crystal.

text: The is the first time I write a review for a book. I listen to this every morning - when I feel the weakest and need a boost of faith in myself. James Clear has explained the teachings of B. F. Skinner in such an easy-to-understand way that anyone can apply them in their daily life. Awesome book! Highly recommend!
title: The One Book That Starts My Day

text: This book is AMAZING! Easy to read, it’s very grounded about how to create good habits and break the bad ones! I even subscribed myself to the author’s newsletter!
title: Impressively grounded

text: The marketing is solid and the concept of "Atomic Habits" is compelling, but everything goes downhill from there.Like so many other productivity books, this is just a collection of one-chapter essays that summarize other people's ideas. The end result is a list of 20+ one-line platitudes like, "Get an accountability partner. Ask someone to watch your behavior." It's at once overwhelming, redundant, and incomplete. You read the book and are left thinking, "OK... so what should I actually do?"I'm sure James is a great person and means well, but that does not mean you should buy his book. (As an alternative, I'd recommend anything written by Cal Newport or Tony Robbins.)
title: A bunch of random tactics

title: Engaging!

text: Over the past few years I have been an avid reader of James Clear’s posts and emails. His blogs and other articles have provided me with a solid structure and framework on habit building thereby driving both achievement and fulfilment in everything I do in life. Whether it is healthy eating, hitting the gym, or keeping my focus in the work environment his advice, tools and approaches have greatly benefited me.I was fortunate enough to get a pre-release copy of Atomic Habits and jumped straight into it. It isn’t a long read, however, it is structured in a way that provides a good overview of why habits are important, tools and techniques on how to establish habits as well as a plethora of real life examples. James also makes reference to an additional set of tools on the Atomic Habits website which you can also leverage (e.g. habit trackers, cheat sheets, guides etc.)The book centres on the both on the four stages of developing a habit and the laws of behaviour change. The latter he delves into in great detail, again with many examples on how to apply within your own life given constraints. The book had a nice pace and balance on theory and application.The biggest thing I have learned (also from his blogs) is the difference between goals and habits. For example, instead of setting a goal, create an identity and establish small habits that align to that identity. For example, don’t say you want to lose weight, but rather identify with being a healthy person that exercises most days and eats well. The habits might be drinking x amount of water a day, 10 push-ups a day, walking 10,000 steps per day etc; and increase the habits once they are firmly established.Given the applicability of this topic, it is a book everyone should read. Unfortunately there are many key areas we don’t get educated on at school. This is one area that is important for life in everything that we do. Highly recommend Atomic Habits!Three key takeaways from the book:1. Habit stacking. Put your clothes out next to your bed before going to sleep so that when you wake up it is the first thing you do or think about. That habit will then drive the habit to go to the gym etc.2. Look to establish identity habits versus reaching for goals or developing finite habits. Habits based on beliefs are much more powerful.3. When it comes to wanting to do something (good or bad) 90% of the dopamine release is driven by the desire versus and 10% on the actual experience.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 17 October 2018

title: Terrible book

text: Decent but seriously overhyped, this book is a watered-down, distorted shadow of Tiny Habits by BJ Fogg.  If this book is from the Stone Age, then Tiny Habits is from the Space Age.  There are critically important, yet subtle points about the behavior change process that Clear misses in Atomic Habits but that Fogg emphasizes in Tiny Habits.  There's coarse advice in Atomic Habits--such as habit contracts and accountability partners--that are probably more harmful than helpful in many situations.  Remember Fogg's sage advice: "I change best by feeling good, not by feeling bad."  Tiny Habits is far more elegant, more concise, and presents a self-contained system that's effective and universal and also explains anything in Clear's book more neatly than Clear presents it himself.  If you have to choose between this book and Tiny Habits, I strongly recommend reading and using Tiny Habits instead.  Even if you've read this book, you should read Tiny Habits to pick up what you've missed out on here and to really calibrate your behavior-change system.  Atomic Habits smacks of being written by a motivational writer with a strong interest in habits who decided to cash in on his large email list with a book deal, while Tiny Habits is written by an actual behavior researcher and educator with a system proven to work on any level and who actually trained tens of thousands of people in his technique before deciding to write a book.  The only way in which Atomic Habits is superior to Tiny Habits is in its discussion of meta-habits (see the section on annual and semiannual reviews).  But even that stuff is freely available online in podcasts and blogs.  I couldn't pick out a single original idea in this book.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 13 June 2020
title: A distorted shadow of Tiny Habits

text: I bought this book because I am a big believer in building habits and predictable routines in one's personal and work life. I read the whole book. I was disappointed.Pros:- Links identity and habits. You are what you do. From that point of view, just going to the gym makes you the type of person who works out, even if you don't do much of a workout.- Introduces the idea that habits bring cumulative benefits like compound interest. While not obviously always the case, it's a powerful idea that definitely applies in areas like meditation or physical training, where the observable changes are minimal at first.Cons:- The book doesn't delve into examples of good habits and the why and how to build them. It stays at the meta / generic level, leaving the reader to think about what habits they may want to build.- The overall principles for building good habits are sound, even if high level and a bit obvious (make the good habits easy, the bad ones hard, etc).- The book is way too long for what it has to convey. Often things repeat or you wonder when the next chapter or thought will start, and when that happens, you lose track of what the earlier one was about -- mainly due to their length.Overall, not recommended.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 May 2019
title: Generic and relatively obvious

text: I've been reading James Clear's work for a long time.  In fact, I can remember his first two blogs, one for photography and the other was Passive Panda.  Since that time his exploration of habits and how to modify them has easily equaled or surpassed the work of Charles Duhigg.I would highly recommend this book to anyone looking to improve and build good habits or stifle and destroy bad ones.  As I have the audio version,  one of the reasons I give the book 4/5 is due to the speed at which he speaks, which is not bad and I admit to being spoilt by the professional narrators of two other audiobooks in, Deep Work and Rejectionproof. The other reason is the reliance on the work of social scientists, psychologists, etc.  I realize that a number of books in the self-improvement space use scientific studies from the above-mentioned fields but the scandals concerning p-hacking and failure to replicate experiments make me wonder how valid the examples in this book and books like it really are.Having said all of that, I would not have stuck with James all these years if he did not provide information that was useful and more importantly, actionable. I look forward to reading whatever he writes next.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 17 October 2018
title: A methodical way to achieve long-term behaviour change.

text: 8/10Atomic Habits is a useful book. It’s a practical guide to identifying and changing your habits. It’s something you can actually put into practice in your life.I think that all of the concepts in the book are good and useful to know but some of the action points I think are slightly oversimplified. If you take the action points in some chapters and modify them to your specific situation you can still apply most of them but you do have to do some critical thinking with the material.I like that the book is simple and straightforward. James Clear doesn’t bog you down with a lot of conceptual material. He starts each chapter with an example (some are better than others), gives you the concept plainly, and then gives you concrete actions to apply the concept in real life. It’s a nice formula. Each chapter is roughly 15-20min.This book is worth reading. It’s easy to apply the knowledge and action steps. Even if it doesn’t completely change your behavior, it will make you more aware of yourself. It provides a good lens that you can use to view yourself and others. I would recommend it to anyone who is trying to really set an air-tight routine. If you follow the book you can definitely make something a habit.I’m a fan of James Clear. I have read his newsletter for about 2yrs now. His newsletter is one of the best I’ve read because it’s interesting and well researched and always has some take away for me. His book is really an expansion on a lot of things he’s covered in his newsletter. There are some chapters that I was already very familiar with because I had read his previous material on it. This doesn’t detract from the book. He expands on most things he’s written about before. The book is laid out like a road map and builds upon itself, which is something you don’t really get from the newsletter.The intro is pretty graphic. It’s about a personal injury the author has faced. I recommend being prepared for that. Once you get through that it’s all good.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 October 2018
title: This is a useful book

text: The most impactful book I've ever read about habits was The Power of Habit....and then Atomic Habits came along. James takes everything I loved about The Power of Habit and expands on it here. The book is chock full of real, practical, and actional advice anyone can take to add more good habits and tweak bad habits over the long term.I was able to listen to a copy and James is a clear narrator who tells an interesting story. He mixes the perfect blend of science and stories to get the point across and make you feel like creating new habits is not some daunting task only for special people but for anyone. I found myself nodding along as I listened and stopped it at least a dozen times to take notes.I got at least 4-5 'a-ha' moments about building habits that shattered the conventional wisdom I'd always thought about before. From realizing that I've been approaching will-power the wrong way and the question that I should ask myself next time I want to lose weight or work out.I've been thinking about Atomic Habits since I finished it and cannot wait to dig into it again. I've been recommending it to everyone.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 October 2018
title: This book can change your life

text: I've been a fan of James Clear since I came across the YouTube video in November 2017, "1% Better Every Day" (I actually have a recurring reminder set up in my task manager every 6 months to rewatch this video since then---absolutely not kidding!).When I heard on The Productivity Show Podcast that James Clear is coming out with this book on 10/16 I purchased it right on the day it got released. I've read over 40 books this year and I'd consider this book to be one of my personal top 3 most impactful book of 2018.I admit that I am a recovering perfectionist and put a lot of pressure on myself to excel at goals I've set out for myself. After reading this book, instead of focusing on goals I've listed out processes and micro habits it will take to "become" the person I want to identify with. I can already feel a huge amount of pressure taken off. Side note: I also love how each chapters start out with a short story relevant to the chapter topic. I look forward to re-reading this book again and reviewing all of my highlighted sections.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 4 November 2018
title: A fan of James Clear even before this book was written

text: Atomic Habits is a beautiful, fancy, and well marketed book. But it's the wrong book if you're serious about self-improvement. It's surface level over a single method of habit formation and is just flat wrong about some of the principles he claims are key to habit formation. For example, using your identity as the base to build your habits on is dangerous. To understand why, I'd suggest the "Awareness" book below. Therefore, if you really want to change read these books instead: - The Willpower Instinct by Kelly McGonigal - Awareness by Anthony de Mell

text: Wow, What a great book!First I love that the author read the audio version help self. I always think you get more hearing it straight from the author and he has a great voice for it.Second, I really appreciate how practical the whole this is. It’s the perfect mix of how-to advice with scientific research and memorable stories.I’m already seeing results from his “Four simple steps to building better habits.” I can see why some habits I’ve tried to create in the past have failed and why some have succeeded. I also really like the bonus downloads he talks about in the book. The Cheat Sheet has been especially helpful.Third, I love that it’s appropriate and engaging for all ages. I’ve listened to a lot of it with my 11 year old and he’s already experimenting with creating new habits to help him focus on his homework. Of course, it’s because he wants to finish early and move on to video games! But I see how appealing of a reward that is for him, so it’s not all bad.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 16 October 2018
title: The Perfect Mix!

text: Everyone has habits that need changing - things you need to stop doing (smoking, procrastinating) and things you need to start doing more of (exercising, writing). This is a useful guide to the tricks you can use to help you develop good habits and rid yourself of bad ones. For example: Habit needs to become part of your identity (not "I have to go the the gym", but "I am a healthy person"). Make good habits easy to do and bad ones inconvenient (put fruit on your kitchen counter, but hide the cookies). Four points are key: Cue-craving-response-reward.All useful stuff - and worth reminding yourself of now and again. But there is nothing terribly new in this book. I preferred Charles Duhigg's earlier "The Power of Habit". This book is worth a quick read, and some of the examples are fun. Certainly, if you follow some of the hints, you will acquire better habits. But not worth five stars.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 18 December 2018
title: Useful - but Duhigg is better

text: I have subscribed to the author's email newsletters for years as I find them both motivating and helpful. His book is similar but is not a rehashed compilation of his emails-- he has actually done a decent amount of research. His biography is also very revealing, having overcome physical hurdles to achieve athletic goals as well as adopting a mindset in college that was different from his peers and allowed him to succeed in the classroom. Clear definitely has some mix of nature and nurture that makes him both intellectually curious and tenacious.To achieve a goal, focus on the habit(s) that help you achieve that goal instead of being fixated on the goal itself. Make performing those habits as easy and natural as possible."Whenever you want to change your behavior, you can simply ask yourself: How can I make it obvious? How can I make it attractive? How can I make it easy? How can I make it satisfying?""Instead of summoning a new dose of willpower whenever you want to do the right thing, your energy would be better spent optimizing your environment.This is the secret to self-control."One challenge I took away from this book is to get into the practice of "habit stacking," setting habits to be performed one after the other:"I will [BEHAVIOR] at [TIME] in [LOCATION].The habit stacking formula is: 'After [CURRENT HABIT], I will [NEW HABIT].'"For example, I have a vague goal of doing more pull-ups. I hung a chin-up bar on a door that I walk past frequently. I have a rule: Every time I walk by the door I do one more pull-up than I did before. A good habit-stacking routine might be to think about one thing I'm thankful for after every pull-up routine. Or to also do one more push-up than I did before. Or, since I have a stack of thank you notes I need to write, I write a thank-you note after every pull-up set."Habits that reinforce your desired identity are usually good. Habits that conflict with your desired identity are usually bad.""Many of our daily habits are imitations of people we admire."Once I start doing pull-ups, I become a guy who exercises-- who does pull-ups. Pull-ups are a challenge for many people, so I can start to develop an identity that I do challenging things.The author also talks about the importance of making such habits pleasurable. Maybe I have a reward that if I do 15 pull-ups in a day, I'll let myself check Facebook. Seeing "likes" on Facebook posts gives me a rush of dopamine. The dopamine becomes the reward from my having done 15 pull-ups."It is the idea of pleasure that we chase. We seek the image of pleasure that we generate in our minds."This book helps you get where you want to be by helping you establish routines where you are today. Focus on the habit and eventually you'll find you've arrived at your goal.4.5 stars out of 5. As a caveat, I find these types of habit books more readily embraced by men than women. My observation is that men have an easier time being rote in their habits; eating the same meals every day (requiring the same preparation, same shopping list, same routine every time). This book had a rather un-emotional feel to it like many other books by men talking about habits and optimization (ie: Tim Ferriss).
date: Reviewed in the United States on 13 September 2019
title: Focus on the habit and the goal will follow

text: Nothing against Charles Duhigg, his book was also very good, but James really brought it home on how to change my horrible habits! It’s a fantastic read, and it is saving me from my emotional eating issues one small teeny tiny habit at a time. Baby steps! His interviews are great too, check him out on YouTube. Great book! Well worth the money, seriously. Quit messing around telling yourself that you will change your habits tomorrow, and get it going TODAY.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 29 October 2018
title: Change your crappy habits one tiny step at a time!

text: This book came to me as amazon recommended. I thought, oh great, another book on building good habits. But I took a glance at it, and decided to look deeper, so I bought a copy. It completely changed my thinking about setting and focusing on goals. I had fallen into the same trap the author writes about. I would set an ambitious goal, with no particular system for achieving that goal. I wasn't consistent about my goals. Sometimes I did the small 1% steps to get to the goal, other times I would do something a few times and give up. It was purely by chance whether I would stick to something or not. What I've learned from the book is to be systematic about my approach. Even more important to to align my identity to the goal I want to achieve.

title: Unexpectedly, I learned something new

text: I love how the book is clearly structured, making the principles easily applied to day to day life. However, the book is a little dry. The anecdotes were appealing but not entertaining enough.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 4 December 2018
title: Clear and well structured book

text: For those who are at times weak-willed creatures of habit vs. logic (like me), this book is life-changing.  As a general rule you know something is spot-on when it had never occurred to you before, but after reading it, it just seems so obvious.  This book is focused mainly on 1) on setting up systems such as your environmental factors of how you make good or bad habits easier or harder for yourself [e.g. having potato chips in plain view on the counter, or putting your workout clothes out the night before] and 2) how to identify habits, set up goals and hold yourself to them.  I haven't achieved every single habit goal yet, but 6 months after finishing the book I've lost 30 pounds and re-instilled a handful of key good habits that I'd been wanting to get back to for years.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 20 August 2020
title: Life changing book for procrastinators like me

text: I like many folks in life have been trying to change things up in my life. This desire for change has picked up greater urgency given the global pandemic. A lot of people are like myself looking at the pandemic and questioning the direction of their life. That’s the mindset in which I decided to read Atomic Habits. From the opening pages, it explodes the conventional mindset a lot of people myself included have that change has to be this big process.The relentless theme of atomic habits is that change is actually a more incremental process and that you are more likely to make the meaningful change if you change one little thing and then carefully add another and another until you don’t even think about doing these things. Eventually if you act with a goal in mind (whatever it is), you will discover that through a series of little changes built upon you are in a much better place regarding your goals and objectives.Atomic Habits really demystified change and reduced it from a thousand pound gorilla and made it more like a seventy-five pound German Shepard Mix. The big thing with change is the mental aspect and I think by following the premise of just doing a little bit, people will have much better results for the longer term. There’s really nothing that’s revolutionary or beyond intuition here, but sometimes the reminder helps.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 25 March 2021
title: The Little Things You Do

text: In short: I expected a lot - and I got it. :)Simple in content, not much new under the sun - but very clear and most of all actionable.Since I am a strong believer of the power of habits, this is a book I will keep rereading once in a while. Most refered books and authors were well known for me, but this does not take away the achievement of the author - who summarizes everything in a crisp and "easy-to-put-into-practice" way. This has NOT been done before by the other authors.I already made some changes, and reinforced some simple atomic habits, while reading te book.Congrats James, you have done well and created a very useful book for your followers.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 November 2018
title: Probably the most practical book I've read on Habits

text: I liked the main idea of the book about focusing on the main thing that needs to be done and letting the other things go. I also appreciated the discussion about the kinds of changes and kinds of habits that could be made (whether it is something you do or something you are).  So the first half of the book seemed really solid and explained a good approach to making incremental changes in your life.  After that, I found the book got distracted from the main theme.  There was discussion about the one thing in this aspect of your life and the one thing in another aspect of your life.  It seemed to me that this violated the overall thesis of the book.  I was somewhat disillusioned with the overall book as I got deeper into it.  But I recommend the book for its overall thesis and making the point about incremental change and focus,
date: Reviewed in the United States on 8 January 2019
title: Interesting approach to making sustainable changes in your life

text: I’ve followed James Clear’s blog for some time now, and he has always been a very easy read. I love similar content to what he writes about, so he is essentially a “shortcut” to learning since he is a more voracious reader/learner than I.I enjoyed this book and think James did a wonderful job piggy-backing off his well-read background while retaining his own unique voice. This was not someone regurgitating what other people have written, but rather him taking all that he has learned and formulating it into a completed puzzle for our consumption.One thing that is tricky with books like this is that they are so easy to read that sometimes you forget they are only useful if you stop, think, and implement the suggestions into your day-to-day. Some books are more about insights and paradigm shifts, while I would say this book is one to study and be disciplined about applying to gain ultimate value from.
date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 December 2018
title: Easily digestible and actionable book backed by research

text: We all have habits good and bad.  If we can shift out of bad habits, and into more good and healthier habits. We would improve our bodies, minds, economics, our families, communities, and our country.  The processes in this book, give a practical methodology to changing your habits, and making more rational decisions that are based on the identity / person we want to become.  If was can understand the Laws of Good Habit Building (Make it Obvious, Attractive, Easy, and Satisfying).  For breaking bad habits (Make it Obscure, Ugly, Difficult, and Painful), you can also combine the two to help motivate you in the right direction.  Wonderful, practical tactics for changing human behavior.  Second, it allows for greater understanding of the "Effects of accumulation results of marginal gains"  If you can improve 1% per week, in a year, you will have improved over 50% which means a fundamental change in who you are in most cases.  You have to set up systems to achieve your goals.  Prepare of unforeseen challenges that LIFE will throw at you.  Prepare three meals at one time, so you only have ONE major clean up instead of three.  Have mini meals ready so when you are hungry, you still stay on plan for your total caloric intake for the day.  It's NOT the goals, but the systems you setup for yourself that determine your success.  When you are about to make a poor food choice, you can ask yourself, "Would a health person eat this?"  If the answer is no, than you are re-enforcing your identity and goals of a healthy person you wish to become.

date: Reviewed in the United States on 17 October 2018
title: I REALLY think this is going to make a difference!

text: Excellent book to read and powerful if you apply it.  The author is clearly an expert at habits.  He uses research, personal experience and fascinating stories to convince us that if we want to change following the advice in Atomic Habits will get us there.An atomic habit is small daily habit with results similar to compound interest.He draws on science from biology, neuroscience, philosophy, psychology, cognitive and behavioral science and more.  He offers us wisdom and practical advice that follow his four-step model of habits, cue, craving, response and reward.  He reviews each step with stories and practical advice.  He shows how to move toward good habits and away from bad habits.I was assigned to read this book as part of a positive psychology master’s class. Here’s a summary of my report on the fourth step, he calls them laws.  The fourth law is to make is satisfying to move towards a good habit and make it unsatisfying to move towards a bad habit.  The amazing story he tells to support this habit is about handwashing.  When Safeguard soap made the experience of handwashing pleasant, nice feel and smell, in Pakistan the overall health improved as more people washed their hands longer.  The rate of diarrhea fell by 52 percent and pneumonia by 48%.  He explains how atomic habits helped the Lakers become the powerhouse NBA team in the eighties, how Chris Rock and Steve Martin became top rated comedians, and why MichaelPhelps genes and habits matter to make him an Olympic Medalist.It’s entertaining, well written and inspiring to read.  More importantly it’s about taking positive action.

date: Reviewed in the United States on 7 December 2018
title: Good habit building and habit stopping framework

text: I've read a ton of non-fiction and business minded books and they all seem to have the secret to getting more out of your life, your business, your relationships, etc. That's all well and good, but the most effective changes - coincidentally - may in fact take the least amount of brainpower. They come in the form of habits, ways our brain have been wired to do things naturally and without thinking, and more importantly, small, daily or near-daily actions that trigger reward centers in our brain.Unfortunately, most of the habits we possess or continue to do are unhealthy or destructive. I.e. chewing nails, eating junk food, or just coming home and watching TV or mindlessly browsing YouTube or scrolling through Instagram. We do these things not because we're weak willed or lazy (most of the time), but because they're the easiest habits to fall into. They're specifically designed and tailored to affect the reward centers of our brain and deliver scheduled shots of dopamine, thus turning them into habits that are hard to kick.Atomic Habits, in a brilliant and knowledgeable way I think, breaks down the ways we can actually achieve more by doing less. And by less, I mean having to expend less effort in willpower, pain, or sacrifice than we're lead to believe. A perfect example in this book is this dancer (I'm forgetting her name) who's world renown and a master of her craft, and who doesn't have to remind herself to go to the gym every day. She instead views the act of going to the gym as walking out her door and hailing a cab to the gym. Once she's done that, everything else takes care of itself. So the habit is not working out, expending sweat, effort, and feeling tired or worn out, which is what many of us find challenging. All she has to do is hail that cab, and she's done, because once she's there she begins to work out. The difference is small, but releases this ability to get that daily workout in which is essential to her success.That's one example of many in this book that challenges one's thinking of how to be successful and create good habits. It's easy to believe it's all a matter of will, of getting motivated, of working off a spark of passion, etc. The truth it is has much more to do with routine, pleasure, familiarity, and route action. I highly recommend this book.

text: This is not a book to read once for fun and then stick it on the shelf.Don’t get me wrong, it’s a terrific read with fascinating stories, examples, and research. (The author’s personal story, which involves a horrifying incident with a baseball bat, gets you turning pages fast.)But the real value is in what you can do with what you learn.I’ve been reading James Clear's blog for a while and was fortunate to get advance access to the book. I’ve gone through it three times already. Took copious notes. Started implementing the techniques. And it’s powerful stuff.Don’t be fooled by the topic — “habits” sounds a bit dreary.But the book is not about figuring out how to plod through life, getting rid of those pesky habits like smoking and getting better at good habits like eating your vegetables.It’s about figuring out what you want to do within your time constraints — what you want to do with your life — and setting up systems that improve your chances of becoming the person you want to be.So buy it, read it, study it, and make these simple techniques part of your life. date: Reviewed in the United States on 3 February 2019
title: Simple, direct...profound

text: I have a lot of bad habits and thought I would give this book a try.  I was first very surprised by how the book started out and the background of the author.  He drew me in with this real-life situation.  I found that my habits can be changed.  His suggestion was to stop setting goals and create small habits that align with your identity and who you want to become.  This will help reach your end result.  So, if your previous mind set was to have a goal to lose weight you should now be wanting to identify as a healthy person.  Then you would create habits like walking so many steps each day, drinking 8 glasses of water each day, or 20 minutes of exercise each day.  Create these habits and then increase the habits over time.  Therefore, walk 200 steps or less starting out and increase overtime until you get to 6,000 more per day.  Now you have a good habit, and the result will be you losing weight but more importantly being a healthier person.  I like this idea because he said habits are the systems needed to lead us to the results we want.  Sometimes we have the wrong systems and don’t see results fast enough and then quit. Bad behaviors repeat themselves not because you don't want to change, but because you're using the wrong system.In the book he also explains that getting 1 percent better every day can add up over time.  I think this is important to those of us who feel like they are not seeing results fast enough.  We need to stick to those good habits. If you're willing to continue with little, seemingly insignificant changes for years, they will compound into extraordinary benefits. The book talks about behavior change at the identity level.  It also talks about habit stacking.  A simple concept to help create better habits.  The book states that any habit may be looked at in a four-step feedback loop: cue, craving, response, and reward.  These are steps to help build good habits as well as how to break the bad ones.  The book gives a set of rules to help change our behaviors and build better habits that include (1) make it obvious, (2) make it attractive, (3) make it easy, and (4) make it satisfying.  I found this very informative and hope to be on my way to break down my own bad habits and build a good habit in its place.  I hope to use more of these techniques talked about in this book to improve my habits.  I would highly recommend this book.
