text: Like many other people , i'm a hardcore procrastinator that would get pumped up and motivated to change my life but eventually get burned out after a couple of weeks of non-stop work when that motivational 'high' wears off . I've lost weight multiple times in the past but only to regain it all back. While some of the concepts in the book aren't new , i've read similar books such as 'Mini Habits' by Stephen Guise , 'The Slight Edge' by Jeff Olson and Kaizen Way by Dr Robert Maurer. Atomic Habits are all those books put together on steroids.James Clear explains how setting goals are not the answer but you should focus on  'systems' instead. The system is simply to repeat good habits everyday by making them easy to do, attractive and rewarding.  Yes it will take some time to see big results but the upside is that they stick for good.I learned how to code ,play the guitar and lost more than 100 pounds thanks to Atomic Habits. This is the best self-help book out there and will change your life!

date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 October 2021
title: Atomic Habits

text: James Clear first came to my attention when an article of his on Pat Reilly’s Lakers analytics was posted to Hacker News. I knew then that I wanted to hear his take on systems thinking, whenever it might be the case that he would have a book ready for public consumption. The result is that, although very little in this short book is wholly original, Clear has done a tremendous service to his readers through his thorough research sorting the wheat from the chaff in the crowded field of behavior modification research. But beyond merely providing a model for habits, Clear has peppered Atomic Habits with actionable tactics. There are also a few diagrams illustrated in this book which I am very thankful to have seen. All of this makes Atomic Habits a brilliant field manual — one which I recommend reading slowly and integrating fully.

title: life Changing

text: “Making a choice that is 1 percent better or 1 percent worse seems insignificant in the moment, but over the span of moments that make up a lifetime these choices determine the difference between who you are and who you could be. Success is the product of daily habits—not once-in-a-lifetime transformations. That said, it doesn’t matter how successful or unsuccessful you are right now. What matters is whether your habits are putting you on the path toward success. You should be far more concerned with your current trajectory than with your current results.“This book is about strategically building your ideal life and your ideal self. It’s so easy to imagine how we wish our lives and ourselves were different, but when it comes to taking action, it can be almost paralyzing. We don’t know where to start, we have unconscious beliefs that sabotage ourselves at every turn, environments that no longer serve us, and action plans that lead to burn out, frustration, and backsliding. James’ book offers solutions to all of these problems. With a little clarity, patience and openmindedness, this book’s wisdom put to use will get you moving towards where you’d like to be.

text: I have read a lot of self help and success books in my day and James Clear’s Atomic habits is truly one of the best!  The principles of the 1% improvement a day  rule through setting up positive habits is the absolute key to truly experiencing the big results in life we are all looking for.  James is also a good writer who makes these vital principles easy to understandand apply.  And his blog is filled with great material as well.  If you really want to see better results in your life,  get this book!  You will be so glad you did!
date: Reviewed in the United States on 27 January 2019
title: One of the best books on success and self help I have read!

text: I initially avoided this book because I thought it would be a hassle to change and record habits. Too much effort...aren't I good enough already? But the whole point of this book is that small, atomic, painless changes can easily be incorporated into your life and pay long term dividends. There are great examples of this mindset, how it works, and you can do as little or as much as you want. I like the idea of "habit stacking" where you simply add something small to something you already do. I'm an old dog, but I've learned some new tricks from this book and I'm using them!
date: Reviewed in the United States on 2 December 2020
title: Painless small (atomic) changes can make a huge difference

text: This is a really useful book. I've read a lot about habits because it's a fascinating subject and because I would like to control mine. Atomic Habits is perfect for the latter purpose.The writing is very straightforward. James Clear deconstructs the habit loop and offers ideas and strategies for making changes at each level in order to help building or getting rid of habits. He talks about the research on which he bases his ideas, and illustrates them with stories, but only as much as it is necessary. The content is focused on applicable ideas and the structure is very easy to follow. He also summarizes each chapter at the end, which is very useful, and offers additional online resources.If you want to create for yourself a strategy for building a good set of habits, this book is great to have around.

date: Reviewed in the United States on 18 April 2019
title: Practical and Useful - Has the Potential to Change Your Life!

text: This is a great book. I have found it the best and most useful book on Habits I have read so far. One of the aha helpful things was the idea that you must first establish your identity, and then the habit (behaviour) reinforces that. Rather than tying to do it the other way around. Viz (quoting from the book): "Doing the right thing is easy. After all, when your behavior and your identity are fully aligned, you are no longer pursuing behavior change, you are simply acting like the type of person you already believe yourself to be."  And "It is a simple two-step process: Decide the type of person you want to be. Prove it to yourself with small wins." and finally to reinforce this point "The most effective way to change your habits is to focus not on what you want to achieve, but on who you wish to become".Also, the author has developed a clear framework called 'The Four Laws of Behavior Change" which provides a simple set of rules (laws) for creating good habits and breaking bad habits. And you are taken step by step through each law, given plenty of practical examples, and there is a summary at the end of each chapter which reinforces the main learning points.Thanks for writing this book Mr James Clear! It has helped me tremendously!

text: Like others who have written reviews I have followed James Clear since he started his blog and find his style of writing appealing because it’s “clear” (no pun intended), pragmatic and believable because he has “clearly” (again, no pun intended) done his homework and thoroughly researched the ideas he presents. Also, like other reviewers, I have read A LOT about habits, behavior change and I’m familiar with premises behind the tiny changes and habit stacking models. When James announced his book release I was excited for his accomplishment and admittedly a bit dubious about what new idea could he possibly add.  I like this guy and he does practice what he preaches but what else can you add to developing positive habits that’s not already been said. Well, after reading Atomic Habits I can honestly say that James Clear has not only added quite a lot but did so in an engaging, enjoyable manner that includes relevant stories and examples.  If you are seeking to change or improve habits then please do yourself a favor and read this book.  Seriously you won’t need all the other books because this one has covered an exhaustive amount of research and makes it easy for you to understand how to change your habits (hint: it’s not you —it’s your system)

title: Can anything new possibly be said about how to change or develop positive habits? Yes!
